docs.lead_paragraph: The job of public advocate of New York City tends to come in for a lot of sniping. The position has a vague mandate -- to ''represent the consumers of city services'' -- and a grab bag of seemingly unrelated responsibilities, from taking over if the mayor resigns to serving as an ex officio member of every City Council committee. The present occupant, Mark Green, turned the job into a platform for this year's mayoral campaign, and his departure has attracted a raft of candidates, some of whom may be hoping to follow in his footsteps. The Democratic primary will choose the next public advocate, since there are no Republican candidates. The leading contenders in the race are two City Council members, Stephen DiBrienza and Kathryn Freed; Betsy Gotbaum, the former parks commissioner; Assemblyman Scott Stringer; and Norman Siegel, the former executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union. Ms. Freed has been a fine member of the Council, but she does not have the breadth of some of the other candidates. Mr. Siegel would certainly be good at the part of the job that involves holding press conferences and criticizing city officials. But we believe this position requires more than experience filing lawsuits.

docs.lead_paragraph: One day in June 1994, Lou Montulli sat down at his keyboard to fix one of the biggest problems facing the fledgling World Wide Web -- and, as so often happens in the world of technology, he created another one. At that moment in Web history, every visit to a site was like the first, with no automatic way to record that a visitor had dropped by before. Any commercial transaction would have to be handled from start to finish in one visit, and visitors would have to work their way through the same clicks again and again; it was like visiting a store where the shopkeeper had amnesia.

headline.main: Giving Web a Memory Cost Its Users Privacy

docs.abstract: First article in three-part series Tracks in Cyberspace, on online privacy; focuses on growing concern over use of 'cookie' data files to help computers running Web sites identify persons visiting them; use has fundamentally altered nature of surfing Web from being relatively anonymous activity to one in which record of one's transactions, movements and even desires are stored, sorted, mined and sold; despite growing public anger over increasing use of data files, momentum in Washington to restrict them and other high-technology tools for monitoring Internet user's activities has slowed; at least 50 bills await consideration, but current leadership in House is focusing attention on privacy invasions by government, not by private business; recent survey by Public Opinion Strategies, Republican polling organization, finds 67 percent of Americans identify online privacy as big concern; diagrams; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Church Avenue in Brooklyn, amid the bustle of stores selling everything from videos and cellular phones to meat patties and jerk chicken, there are clear signs of a lively political campaign. Huge posters hang in stores, slogan-covered poster boards ride atop cars roaming the streets, and candidates work frenetically at subway stations. The 40th Council District is a largely Caribbean enclave of Flatbush and East Flatbush, an area that 10 years ago elected the first Jamaican-born woman to serve in the City Council, Una S. T. Clarke. Because of the city's term limit laws, Ms. Clarke is ineligible to run for re-election this year. Six candidates hope to succeed her, including Ms. Clarke's daughter.

headline.main: Vying to Help Businesses at Heart of Caribbean Enclave

docs.abstract: Article on race for New York City Council seat in 40th district in Brooklyn; campaigns of candidates Edward A Roberts, Yvette D Clarke, Wellington Sharpe, Frances G Purcell, Jean D Vernet and Alithia Alleyne discussed; all of candidates have Caribbean roots; some of election issues detailed; photo; map; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Belkin's focus on the decidedly unsympathetic Melinda Ballard diminished the impact of her coverage of a serious health issue and did little to add to the credibility of those seeking real solutions to the problem. Ballard spent too much time wrangling with insurance companies and too little of her personal fortune in tackling the problem of toxic molds in her mansion. A more effective focus of the article would have been the Montoya family -- people who don't have the cash or clout to aggressively pursue legal remedies. Rick Lyon Bloomfield, N.J.
docs.abstract: Rick Lyon letter holds Lisa Belkin's August 12 article on house molds should have focused on Montoya family rather than Melinda Ballard and her family

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, roughly five months after his near-fatal ski accident, the former Olympic champion Bill Johnson will walk, perhaps with assistance, from the California rehabilitation center where he has been receiving 24-hour care and intensive therapy to retrain him in the routine skills of daily life. ''My mom is going to take care of me now,'' Johnson said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ''I'm not going to be able to do everything myself, but I'll be at home with my mom and that's just fine with me.''

headline.main: After Accident, Johnson Is Charting a Daring Recovery

docs.abstract: Former Olympic skiing champion Bill Johnson continues recovery from skiing accident that left him in coma, as he leaves rehabilitation center and moves to his mother's home; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An old friend has fallen on hard times. She, her husband and three young children are on food stamps and a state-financed health plan. To help out, my husband and I hired her husband to paint our house. In the middle of the job, she said they wrote on an insurance form that we pay him $200 a week. In reality, it is much more. An official will call us to verify the figure. If we tell the truth, they will lose their insurance, so we intend to lie. How unethical are we? Anonymous, Portland, Ore. You are not nearly as unethical as the ''friend'' who maneuvers you into this dilemma: defraud the government or deprive her children of health insurance.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 09-02-01: The ethicist; Kiddie Scam

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist question-and-answer column on ethics of agreeing to lie about amount of wages paid to friend to paint house if it means his children will lose health insurance provided by state, whether uncollected Metro-North train tickets should be turned in or used again and whether recipient of errant personal file stolen by e-mail virus has right to read it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LITTLE SILVER, on the Shrewsbury River in Monmouth County, is in the throes of a home renovation and expansion boom. Throughout the 2.8-square-mile borough, roofs are being ripped off ranch houses and small Cape Cods, as they are converted into sprawling two-story colonials. Many homes -- sometimes several on one block -- are being torn down to make way for larger ones. ''Last year, we issued 581 building permits and during the first seven months of this year we issued another 403,'' Mayor Suzanne S. Castleman said. ''Since we have virtually no buildable land left, these are mostly improvements to existing homes.''

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/Little Silver, N.J.; Riverfront Borough That Prizes Stability

docs.lead_paragraph: The four main Democratic candidates seeking to become New York's next mayor moved out across the five boroughs yesterday, exhorting voters to pay attention in the last days of a low-flying contest that will help determine what the city will look like once Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani leaves City Hall on Dec. 31. Operating under some unusual restraints, from a legal ceiling on campaign spending to a sitting mayor's unwillingness to cede the spotlight, the candidates took advantage of a sparkling holiday weekend, searching for stray voters and ways to rise above a crowded field.

headline.main: Democrats Run In the Shadow Cast by Mayor

docs.abstract: Four main Democratic candidates seeking to become New York's next mayor campaign across five boroughs, restrained by legal ceiling on campaign spending and Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani's unwillingness to cede spotlight; candidates return to themes they conclude can lift them to victory in Sept 11 primary; City Counmcil speaker, Peter F Vallone, and Comptroller Alan G Hevesi head to Staten Island, where they appeal to moderate and conservative Democrats; public advocate, Mark Green, and Fernando Ferrer, Bronx borough president, campaign among black voters in Harlem; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE swan on Georgica Pond was on a tear. Vehemently protective of some newborns, it had attacked several paddlers, said the clerk renting us our kayaks at the Main Beach Surf and Sport store in East Hampton in early July. One panicked woman had her face bloodied by a massive raised wing, we were told, and one man, the clerk added kind of gleefully, ended up falling into the water and spraining his arm. ''If he comes after you, get away from him fast,'' he said as he handed us life vests. ''But if he actually attacks, just raise your paddle and show him you're the boss.'' We had to do so, and got past him unharmed, although it was close.
docs.abstract: Bob Morris column on resort anxiety he perceives in Hamptons this summer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation today requiring insurance companies that offer pregnancy-related benefits to also provide coverage for a wide range of infertility treatments. The legislation, which has been criticized by insurance companies, makes New Jersey the 15th state to enact legislation regarding infertility therapy. The scope of the laws varies widely from state to state, but advocacy groups called the New Jersey law a reasonable compromise that includes provisions for costly treatments like in vitro fertilization, but that also limits when such methods can be used.

headline.main: Insurers Offering Pregnancy Benefits Now Must Cover Fertility
